case_vignette: A 76-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with an intense, throbbing, right-sided headache. She has a history of migraine headaches and tried her usual medications this afternoon with no alleviation of symptoms. She states that this headache feels different because she also has pain in her jaw that is worse with chewing. The pain came on gradually and is getting worse. In addition, over the past few months, she has had some difficulty getting up out of chairs and raising both her arms over her head to put on her clothes. She has had no recent falls or injuries. On exam, the patient's temperature is 98.3°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg, pulse is 93/min, and respirations are 15/min. The patient has tenderness over her right temple. She has no focal neurological deficits, and no abnormalities on fundoscopic exam. Her physical exam is otherwise within normal limits.
question: Given the patient's most likely diagnosis, which  methods of treatment should be used in order to prevent any further complications?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Rheumatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have an intense, throbbing headache on the right side of my head, and my jaw hurts when I chew.
How old are you and what is your sex?
I'm a 76-year-old woman.
Have you experienced any changes in your vision?
No, I haven't noticed any changes in my vision.
Do you have any tenderness or pain on your scalp, like when brushing your hair?
Yes, there's tenderness over my right temple.
Have you noticed any weight loss, fatigue, fever, or general malaise recently?
No, I haven't noticed weight loss, fatigue, fever, or a general feeling of being unwell.
Do you have any history of arthritis or other autoimmune diseases?
No, I don't have a history of arthritis or other autoimmune diseases.
Are you currently on any medications?
Yes, I tried my usual migraine medications this afternoon, but they didn't help.
Have you ever been diagnosed with migraine, or is this a new type of headache for you?
I have a history of migraine headaches.
Is this headache different in intensity, location, or symptoms from your usual migraines?
Yes, this headache feels different because I also have pain in my jaw that worsens with chewing.
Do you have a personal or family history of cancers or blood disorders?
No, I have no recent history of cancers or blood disorders.
Have you noticed any muscle aches or stiffness in your neck, shoulders, or hips?
Yes, I've had difficulty getting up from chairs and raising my arms over my head to put on clothes.
Final Diagnosis: Giant Cell Arteritis (Temporal Arteritis)

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A 76-year-old woman presents with an intense, throbbing headache on the right side of her head, and reports feeling pain in her jaw when she chews. She confirms that she has not noticed any changes in her vision and has tenderness over her right temple. She denies weight loss, fatigue, fever, or a general feeling of being unwell, and has no history of arthritis or other autoimmune diseases. She tried her usual migraine medications, which did not provide relief. She notes that this headache feels different because of the accompanying jaw pain that worsens with chewing. She also reports difficulty getting up from chairs and raising her arms over her head to put on clothes.
trial_0.vignette_frq: Given the most likely diagnosis of giant cell arteritis, the patient should be started on high-dose corticosteroids to prevent further complications, such as vision loss. Immediate referral to a specialist may be necessary, and additional evaluation, including temporal artery biopsy and imaging, may be considered to confirm the diagnosis.
trial_0.summarized_frq: The patient's most likely diagnosis is Giant Cell Arteritis (Temporal Arteritis). Treatment should include high-dose corticosteroids to prevent further complications, such as visual loss.
